facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 274 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 274 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27,1956, of the Madras High Court, in C.R.P. No. 90 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27,1956, of the Madras High Court, in C.R.P. No. 90 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 27,1956, of the Madras High Court, in C.R.P. No. 90 of 1955. C. Chatterjee, R. Ganapathy Iyer and G. Gopalakrishnan for the appellant. N. Rajagopala Sastri, R. Mahalinga Iyer and M. S. K. Aiyengar, for respondent No. 1. 1960. November, 28.

facts.text: S.V.N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons were adjudged insolvents on an application of Smt. Engammal (respondent).

anchor.surface_text: The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these. S.V.N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons were adjudged insolvents on an application of Smt. Engammal  hereinafter referred to as the respondent . They had preferred an appeal before the High Court of Madras but it was dismissed on April 17, 1953.

facts.text: Appeal by insolvents to High Court of Madras dismissed on April 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They had preferred an appeal before the High Court of Madras but it was dismissed on April 17, 1953. Thereafter the official receiver took steps to sell the property of the insolvents, which companysisted of two lots, the first lot companyprising 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house, and the second lot, 8 acres and odd of dry land.

facts.text: Properties of insolvents: first lot comprising 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house, second lot 8 acres and odd of dry land. Both subject to mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the official receiver took steps to sell the property of the insolvents, which companysisted of two lots, the first lot companyprising 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house, and the second lot, 8 acres and odd of dry land. Both these properties were subject to mortgage.

facts.text: Official receiver fixed September 28, 1953, for sale of the properties by auction.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver fixed September 28, 1953, for sale of the properties by auction. Fifteen of the creditors were present when the sale by auction took place, including the son of the respondent.

facts.text: Fifteen creditors present at auction, including son of respondent. No request for postponing the sale.

anchor.surface_text: Fifteen of the creditors were present when the sale by auction took place, including the son of the respondent. No request was made on that day by anyone for postponing the sale and companysequently bids were made.

facts.text: Highest bid for lot 1: Rs. 4500/- by appellant (brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker). Highest bid for lot 2: Rs. 70/- by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The highest bid for lot 1 was of Rs. 4500/- and the highest bid for lot 2 was of Rs. 70/-. Both these bids were made by the appellant who is a brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker.

facts.text: Encumbrance on entire property: Rs. 17,200/-

anchor.surface_text: The reason why the two lots were sold for Rs. 4570/- was that there was an encumbrance on the entire property of Rs. 17,200/-.

facts.text: Official receiver postponed sale to various dates up to October 26, 1953, hoping for higher offers.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver did number close the sale on that day in the hope that some higher offers might be made by the creditors and postponed it to various dates upto October 26, 1953.

facts.text: Respondent's son present on postponement dates, no higher offer by respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On all these dates, the respondents son was present but numberhigher offer was made on behalf of the respondent.

facts.text: On October 26, 1953, application by respondent to postpone sale for three months due to drought.

anchor.surface_text: On October 26, 1953, an application was made on behalf of the respondent praying that the sale be postponed for another three months apparently on the ground that there had been drought in that area for some years past and agricultural lands were number fetching good price.

facts.text: Official receiver refused to postpone and knocked down properties to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver, however, saw numberreason to postpone the sale, particularly when numberhigher offer was forthcoming from the side of the respondent and decided to knock down the properties in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: November 18, 1953, respondent applied under s. 68 of Provincial Insolvency Act claiming inadequate price due to drought, offered to bid more than Rs. 7500/- if postponed.

anchor.surface_text: Later, an application was made on behalf of the respondent on November 18, 1953 under s. 68 of the Provincial Insolvency Act, No. V of 1920  hereinafter referred to as the Act . The case of the respondent was that the sale had been made for a very inadequate price and there had been drought in the village for several years in the past and there was very great stringency in the money market and it was hoped that if the sale was postponed for three or four months, the properties would fetch a good price of number less than Rs. 15,000/-, exclusive of the sum due on the encumbrances.

facts.text: Respondent alleged collusion between official receiver, insolvent, and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent also stated that if the sale was postponed for three months she would be prepared to bid more than Rs. 7500/- for the properties. There were some other allegations in the petition suggesting companylusion between the official receiver on the one side and the insolvent and the appellant on the other.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge allowed respondent's s.68 application on ground price low, creditors (debts Rs.30,000/-) prejudiced.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge allowed the application on the ground that the price fetched was low and that the general body of creditors to whom debts to the extent of Rs. 30,000/- were payable would be companysiderably prejudiced if the sale was allowed to stand.

facts.text: District Judge allowed appeal under s.75, found no irregularity, no collusion, price not low.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an appeal to the District Judge under s. 75 of the Act. The District Judge allowed the appeal. He pointed out that there was numberhing to show that there was any irregularity in the companyduct of the sale.

facts.text: High Court in revision under proviso to s.75 accepted respondent's offer to deposit Rs.9,000/-, bid at Rs.9,000/-, pay Rs.1,000/- to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the High Court an offer was made by the respondent that she was prepared to deposit Rs. 9,000/- if a fresh auction was held and would start the bid at Rs. 9,000/- and also that she would pay Rs. 1,000/- to the appellant for any loss caused to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside High Court order, restored District Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the District Judge.

facts.text: Debts to creditors: Rs. 30,000/-

anchor.surface_text: the general body of creditors to whom debts to the extent of Rs. 30,000/- were payable would be companysiderably prejudiced

facts.text: Properties mortgaged for over Rs. 20,000/- in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: He came to the companyclusion that the properties would be worth at least Rs. 40,000/- and the main reason why he said so was that the properties had been mortgaged for over Rs. 20,000/- in 1936.

facts.text: Insolvents deposited Rs. 2000/- annually to High Court to remain in possession during appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge also pointed out that the insolvents were in possession of the properties during the pendency of the insolvency appeal and had been depositing Rs. 2000/- annually on the order of the High Court in order to remain in possession.

facts.text: No fraud or collusion found by Subordinate Judge and District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Now both the Subordinate Judge and the District Judge found that there was numberreason to hold that there was any fraud or companylusion on the part of the official receiver in this case.

facts.text: No irregularity in conduct of sale found by District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Further, the Subordinate Judge did number find that there was any irregularity companymitted by the official receiver in companyducting the sale and the District Judge has definitely found that there was numbersuch irregularity.

facts.text: Drought in the area for some years past, affecting land prices.

anchor.surface_text: apparently on the ground that there had been drought in that area for some years past and agricultural lands were number fetching good price.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the District Judge under the proviso to s. 75 unless it came to the conclusion that the order was not according to law

anchor.surface_text: It is this order of the High Court which has been brought before us by special leave and the only question that has been urged on behalf of the appellant is that the High Court had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the District Judge unless it came to the conclusion that the order was not according to law.

issues.text: Whether there were good grounds justifying interference with the official receiver's sale under s. 68, such as fraud, collusion, irregularity in conduct of sale, or price so low as to shock the conscience

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the power of the court under s. 68 in no hedged in by those considerations which apply in cases of auction sales in execution proceedings. Even so, the power under s. 68 is a judicial power and must be exercised on well recognised principles, justifying interference with an act of the receiver which he is empowered to do under s. 59 a of the Act. ... These grounds may be, for example, that there was fraud or collusion between the receiver and the insolvent or the intending purchaser the court may be also interfere if it is of opinion that there were irregularities in the conduct of the sale which might have affected the price fetched at the sale again, even though there may be no collusion, fraud or irregularity, the price fetched may still be so low as to justify the court to hold that the property should not be sold at that price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court order shows no application of mind to proviso requirement; influenced by irrelevant later offer made three years after auction.

holdings.text: Power under s.68 is not hedged in by considerations applicable to auction sales in execution proceedings but is a judicial power exercised on well-recognised principles justifying interference with receiver's acts under s.59A.

anchor.surface_text: It may be accepted that the power of the companyrt under s. 68 in number hedged in by those companysiderations which apply in cases of auction sales in execution proceedings. Even so, the power under s. 68 is a judicial power and must be exercised on well recognised principles, justifying interference with an act of the receiver which he is empowered to do under s. 59  a  of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acknowledges wider scope than execution sales but emphasizes judicial nature and need for principled exercise, not arbitrary.

holdings.text: Court under s.68 must prioritize interests: general body of creditors first, insolvent second, intending purchaser last.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the companyrt has to look in insolvency proceedings to the interest in the first place of the general body of creditors in the second place to the interest of the insolvent, and lastly, where a sale has been decided upon by the official receiver to the interest of the intending purchaser in that order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hierarchy guides exercise of discretion in insolvency sales to protect creditors primarily.

holdings.text: Receiver's sale decision not to be set aside unless good judicial grounds like fraud/collusion, irregularities affecting price, or grossly inadequate price shocking conscience.

anchor.surface_text: These grounds may be, for example, that there was fraud or companylusion between the receiver and the insolvent or the intending purchaser the companyrt may be also interfere if it is of opinion that there were irregularities in the companyduct of the sale which might have affected the price fetched at the sale again, even though there may be numbercollusion, fraud or irregularity, the price fetched may still be so low as to justify the companyrt to hold that the property should number be sold at that price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Articulates specific grounds wider than execution but requiring judicial justification; applies to facts finding none present.

holdings.text: No fraud, collusion or irregularities in the conduct of the sale warranting interference under s.68.

anchor.surface_text: Now both the Subordinate Judge and the District Judge found that there was numberreason to hold that there was any fraud or companylusion on the part of the official receiver in this case. Further, the Subordinate Judge did number find that there was any irregularity companymitted by the official receiver in companyducting the sale and the District Judge has definitely found that there was numbersuch irregularity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts findings of both lower courts that no such vices present.

holdings.text: Price fetched not inadequate as no evidence of proper valuation by recognised methods accounting for encumbrances; Subordinate Judge's doubling of 1936 mortgage erroneous.

anchor.surface_text: It was open to the respondent to show to the Subordinate Judge by well recognised methods of valuation as to what the value of the properties was. The Subordinate Judge should have then taken into account the total amount of the encumbrance on these properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects speculative valuation; requires recognised methods minus encumbrances to show gross inadequacy; no such proof.

holdings.text: District Judge's order holding price not low and reversing Subordinate Judge was according to law.

anchor.surface_text: In these circumstances, it is number possible for us to say that the order of the District Judge when he held that the Subordinate Judge was number right in holding that the price fetched was inadequate or unreasonable, is number according to law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: DJ correctly applied lack of evidence for inadequacy; no mistake in law.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the District Judge.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court order set aside; District Judge's order restored.
directions: set aside the order of the High Court
restore the order of the District Judge

anchor.surface_text: As the High Court did number companysider the question whether the order of the District Judge was according to law or number and did number companye to the companyclusion that order was number according to law, the High Court would have numberjurisdiction to interfere with that order.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the District Judge.

It may be accepted that the power of the companyrt under s. 68 in number hedged in by those companysiderations which apply in cases of auction sales in execution proceedings. Even so, the power under s. 68 is a judicial power and must be exercised on well recognised principles, justifying interference with an act of the receiver which he is empowered to do under s. 59  a  of the Act.
We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the District Judge.
